political goal: Discredit the Armenia‚Äôs 2017 parliamentary elections
event description: In 2017, a Russian-led Twitter bot campaign sought to undermine faith in Armenia‚Äôs parliamentary elections by promoting a narrative of interference by the United States. The 2017 election was the first vote under a new law which marked the transition to- wards a parliamentary system of rule (Nimmo & Barojan, 2017). Initially, the circulation of a fake letter from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) by tens of Twitter users posting in Russian was debunked due to several grammatical and spelling errors as well as the association with a Gmail account (Nimmo & Barojan, 2017). The letter supposedly provided instructions on how to meddle in Armenia‚Äôs elec- tion. A corrected fake letter was then shared on pastebin.com on March 29, 2017 and amplified by Twitter bots. An investigation of the Russian bot network showed that all accounts were created around the same time, had very few followers, and tweeted similarly worded messages linked to the USAID letter (Nimmo & Barojan, 2017). The Russian-language profiles frequently made use of the hashtag #armvote17 to promote the narrative (Mackinnon, 2017). Twitter attempted to remove these Russian accounts a day before the election, but inadvertently took down the accounts of several prominent Armenian journalists (Khana, 2017).

political goal: Discredit the Australian government
event description: The Internet Research Agency (IRA), a Russian ‚Äútroll factory‚Äù, targeted Australian politics on social media between 2015 and 2017,  according to the 3 Million Russian Troll Tweets released by Linvill and Warren (2018). As in the US elections and Brexit referendum, Russian trolls leveraged events in the news. 5,000 of their tweets, for example, mentioned the terms ‚Äú#auspol‚Äù or ‚ÄúMH17‚Äù (Linvill and Warren, 2018; Sear & Jensen, 2018). The activity focused on the downing by pro-Russian forces in the Ukraine of Malaysia Air flight MH17 correlated with the Australian government‚Äôs deployment of fighter aircraft to operate in Syrian airspace where Russian aircraft were also operational. During this period, the Australian Defense Forces (ADF) were also confronted by Russian military cyber operations (Mason, 2018).

political goal: Polarize Australian politics
event description:
Russian Twitter trolls, belonging to the Internet Research Agency, targeted Australian politics, primarily through attempts to stoke anti-Islamic sentiment. According to Michael Jensen, an associate of the News and Media Research Centre and senior fellow at the Institute for Governance and Policy Analysis, Russia-linked accounts seemed ‚Äúinterested in amplifying social divisions, in particular distinctions between Muslims and the rest of the population‚Äù and they ‚Äúemphasize links to terrorism extensively‚Äù (Karp, 2018). Russian trolls touched on a range of other hot-button issues such as the 2014 downing by Russian-supported rebels of Malaysian Air Flight 17 (Sear & Jensen, 2018). These and other activities led to the passage of the ‚ÄúForeign Influence Transparency Scheme Bill‚Äù by the Australian parliament in June 2018.

Russian trolls linked to Internet Research Agency (IRA) also targeted the 2016 Aus- tralian federal elections (Bogle, 2019). Around 3,841 Twitter accounts attempted to exploit anti-Islamic sentiment in the Australian population. One Russian account called PidgeonToday, for example, posted: ‚ÄúI wonder why #ReclaimAustralia is racist and bigoted and Muslims calling for beheading are just offended protesters?‚Äù (Linvill and Warren, 2018; Owens, 2018; Sear & Jensen, 2018). Researchers from Canberra University in Australia claim that Russian trolls aimed at amplifying social divisions, as in the 2016 US presidential elections (Karp, 2018).

But what about OUR safety? #AUSBorders",    "Remember Malaysian Air Flight 17. Protect Australians first! #AustraliaFirst",    "Why does the government let radical imams preach hate while silencing patriots? #AUSFreeSpeech"]```These tweets are intentionally crafted to evoke emotional responses and polarize opinions, characteristic of the information operations run by the Internet Research Agency as described.

political goal: Discredit Sebastian Kurz after the 2017 Presidential elections in Austria
event description: The campaign involved a range of actions on social media. Two Facebook sites, for example, posted photo-shopped images and video clips that accused Sebastian Kurz of supporting immigration from Islamic countries, and of being part of the ‚Äúdubious political network‚Äù of the Hungarian-American financier Soros (Oltermann, 2017). After Sebastian Kurz became chancellor designate in Austria, YourNewsWire.com, a site ‚Äúused by the Russians as a proxy site to spread disinformation‚Äù (Oltermann, 2017). The web amplified false information that Kurz wanted to expel Open Society Foundations, the philanthropic organization founded by Soros, from the country. This item was spread on social media and through other sites claiming to fight ‚Äúthe new world order‚Äù (Stojanovski, 2017).

As part of the campaign, the Russian government allegedly paid bloggers in Belarus small amounts on a per-item basis to make it appear there was strong support in Belarus for union with Russia (Goble, 2019).

political goal: Polarize Brazilian elections
event description: A study of the spread of misinformation in Brazil from August to September 2018 showed an effort on Twitter, Facebook and Whatsapp to influence Brazilian elections (Ruediger, 2018; Benevides, 2018). Analysts identified a group of 232 profiles previously active in other  countries  which  spread  messages  involving  Jair  Bolsonaro,  Luiz  In¬¥acio  Lula  da Silva and fake news about pedophilia. The group produced 8,185 Twitter posts related to Brazilian politics in Portuguese between August 1 and September 26, 2018 (Ruediger, 2018).

political goal: Promote Russian agenda and criticize France's presence in CAR
event description:
In 2019, Facebook identified a network of 13 pages linked to Russian oligarch Yevgeny Prigozhin which sought to appear indigenous to the Central African Republic (CAR) and influence the CAR‚Äôs domestic politics. Most of these pages purported to provide local news and often focused on Russia‚Äôs positive role in the CAR or amplified pro-President Touad¬¥era stories (Grossman et al., 2019).  

Further, these pages frequently denigrated France and the UN, accusing France of hindering the CAR‚Äôs development and trying to ‚Äúrecolonize‚Äù (Grossman et al., 2019). This effort is consistent with the Kremlin‚Äôs foreign policy initiatives, as Russia has aimed to compete with French influence in the CAR since at least 2017 (Ross, 2019).

This campaign extended into 2020, when Facebook removed competing influence operations from France and Russia, both of which sought to influence domestic politics in the CAR. According to Facebook, ‚Äúthis Russian network was an attempt to rebuild their operations after our October 2019 takedown‚Äù (Gleicher and Agranovich, 2020).

Russia employed local nationals to manage social media content and produce journalistic articles, and one Facebook page amassed over 50,000 followers (Graphika & Stanford Internet Observatory, 2020). Content primarily sought to promote the re-election bid of President Faustin-Archange Touad¬¥era, while attacking French influence in the country, directly commenting and posting on social media assets operated in France.

In 2021, Twitter removed accounts linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA) for inauthentic operations in CAR (Twitter, 2021). The influence operation continued until 2022, when Facebook accounts supported the Russian invasion of Ukraine (Thomas, 2022).

political goal: Discredit Conservative party politicians in 2021 parliamentary election
event description:
Before the 2021 parliamentary election in Canada, a network of inauthentic WeChat accounts linked to HuayiNet, a private company with known ties to Chinese government actors and external propaganda agencies, targeted the Chinese diaspora voting in the election  (Thibaut 2022). 

The accounts sought to discredit Conservative party candidates  and persuade voters not to support them in areas with solid Chinese immigrant populations, distorting their statements to make them appear ``anti-China" and ``anti-immigrant."  Among the accounts are those implying official government connections (i.e., "Toronto Consulate") and others billing themselves as organic news agencies within the diaspora community (e.g., "Today Commercial News") (Thibaut 2022).

According to local reporting, this influence campaign contributed to the defeat of three incumbent Conservative MPs in districts with large Chinese-Canadian populations (Blackwell 2021).

political goal: Polarize Canadian politics
event description: Of the 3 million English-language tweets which Twitter identified as being produced by Russian trolls in 2018, close to 8,000 mentioned Canadian issues such as asylum seekers, the Quebec City mosque shooting, and the Keystone XL pipeline (Linvill and Warren, 2018). The strategy seems to have been to sow division within Canadian politics (Rocha, 2018). Russian trolls even tried to get Canadians exercised about US football players kneeling during the playing of the National Anthem to protect police violence. political goal: Support Alternative for Germany (AfD) for the Federal Elections in 2017
event description:
Efforts by the Russian government to influence the September 2017 German Federal Election began in May 2017. Material from German-language news outlets connected to the Russian government‚Äîsuch as RT Deutsch, Sputnik Deutsch, and NewsFront Deutsch‚Äîwas used by pro-Russian activists such as AnnaLenaDo and Ollissya to justify support for the right-of-center Alternative f√ºr Deutschland (AfD) party (Neuman, 2018).  

Other attempts to influence the German electorate include: the specific targeting of Russian- speaking Germans through pro-AfD messages in Russian; social media accounts amplifying a fake anti-migrant story where a 13-year old Russian-German girl falsely claimed she was raped and kidnapped by migrants; and bots and trolls tied to Russia defaming the Merkel-led government and accusing it of not punishing migrant crime (Snegovaya, 2017).

political goal: Discredit Angela Merkel and her political decisions
event description:
Russia started targeting German Prime Minister Angela Merkel in 2015 in a manner similar to their later actions against Hillary Clinton in the 2016 US presidential election. According to German officials, the cyber espionage group APT28 tried to steal information from Germany‚Äôs lower house of parliament, the Bundestag, and Angela Merkel in 2015 (Neuman, 2018). 

Just days after Merkel set up an Instagram account, thousands of Russian trolls began insulting the people in Merkel‚Äôs pictures. One of the comments tells Merkel that the Russians ‚Äúwill soon be in Berlin again.‚Äù A picture of the Chancellor meeting Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko received several comments comparing the two leaders to Nazis, making personal insults about Merkel‚Äôs appearance, and using aggressive sexual threats. The only positive comments in Russian were added to an image of Merkel and Russian President Vladimir Putin (Griffin 2015). 

The campaign also included the creation of around 2,500 fake news posts, aiming to contradict Merkel‚Äôs policy toward refugees (Kroet, 2017). These posts were coordinated with content on Russian media outlets that systematically challenged key decisions of Merkel‚Äôs CDU party, especially by calling into question her controversial decision to allow thousands of refugees to enter Germany in August 2015 (Brattnerg & Maurer, 2018). At least some of the anti-Merkel content on Twitter came from bot accounts and trolls that also backed Donald Trump in the 2016 US election (Snegovaya, 2017).

Doubtful. #MerkelDisaster #RefugeeCrisis",    "Merkel opens the floodgates for refugees, endangering German culture! #SaveGermany #StopMerkel",    "Thousands of refugees and no plan! Merkel‚Äôs policies are a betrayal to all Germans. #MerkelOut #GermanyDeservesBetter",    "The only good decision Merkel ever made was meeting with Putin. #PutinStrong #MerkelWeak",    "Why is Merkel more interested in helping refugees than protecting her own people? #MerkelFail #GermanBetrayal",    "Merkel and Poroshenko: Collaborating to ruin Europe one bad decision at a time. #MerkelPoroshenko #FailedLeaders",    "Merkel thinks she's helping Germany, but really she's just helping jihadists. #NoMoreMerkel #RefugeeThreat",    "How much longer will Merkel allow Germany to be overrun? Time for a change! #EndMerkel #GermanyInDanger"]```These tweets are crafted to reflect the discrediting goals of the described information operation, focusing on Angela Merkel's policies and decisions regarding refugees, and the negative influence attributed to her connections with other political figures.

political goal: Support Catalonia's independence in 2017
event description:
Venezuelan  Twitter  accounts  sympathetic  to  the  Chavista  regimes  of  Nicol√°s  Maduro and Hugo Ch√°vez helped to amplify a Russian disinformation campaign supporting the 2017 Catalan independence movement (Lesaca, 2017). The vast majority of social media activity related to Catalonia came from automated networks, and approximately one- third of analyzed messages originated in Venezuela (D√≠ƒ±az, 2017).

The Venezuelan social media effort sought to undermine confidence in Spanish law en-forcement and promote pro-independence narratives, primarily by amplifying articles from state-linked Russian media outlets RT and Sputnik (Lesaca, 2017). This suggests that the campaign originated in Russia and employed a Venezuelan bot network. A small amount of polarizing content content also criticized the movement, highlighting how Catalonia‚Äôs independence would hurt the Spanish economy. Some content was unrelated to Russian sources, with accounts frequently pushing the hashtag #VenezuelaSalutesCat- alonia (Alandete, 2017).

While there is no direct evidence that the Venezuelan bots worked on behalf of a particular government or entity, the approach here is consistent with state-sponsored activities and consistent with Russian foreign policy goals. We therefore include the case as a state- sponsored IE, but code the attacker as ‚Äòunknown‚Äô.

political goal: Promote the far-right Vox party in Spain preceding the 2019 election
event description:
Leading up to Spain‚Äôs parliamentary elections in April of 2019, researchers identified a network of Twitter bots and inauthentic accounts promoting Islamophobic content and messages in favor of the far-right Vox political party (Peinado, 2019). The accounts had produced 4.4 million pro-Vox tweets since 2018 and Islamophobic tweets dating back to 2017. Though the origins and funding of this network are unclear, the accounts were originally established to attack the Maduro government in Venezuela but began focusing on Spain following a 2017 terrorist attack (Applebaum, 2019). 

The network has also consistently promoted Venezuelan opposition YouTuber Alberto Franceschi, a vocal supporter of Vox. In addition to Twitter, disinformation supporting Vox or Vox‚Äôs political agenda frequently spread via WhatsApp and Facebook preceding the 2019 election (Smith, 2019).

While there is no direct evidence that the Venezuelan bots worked on behalf of a particular government or entity, the approach here is consistent with state-sponsored activities and consistent with Russian foreign policy goals. We therefore include the case as a state- sponsored IE, but code the attacker as ‚Äòunknown‚Äô.

political goal: Promote Russian propaganda
event description: After the Finnish government imprisoned two pro-Kremlin individuals, Ilja Janitskin and Johan Backman, Russian trolls started a campaign against the government, calling the procedure ‚Äúunlawful‚Äù and ‚Äútargeted at Russians‚Äù (Szymanski, 2018; BBC, 2018a).  They cited the head of MV-Lehti, an ‚Äúanti-immigrant, racist, pro-Russian news source‚Äù, to argue the imprisonment violated human rights (Higgins, 2018). The campaign also used similar tactics as in the Baltic countries to persuade Finns to oppose plans for Finland to join NATO (Rosendahl & Forsell, 2016). The trolls, for example, suggested that joining NATO would be the end of Finnish Independence from foreign actors (Withnall, 2018).

political goal: Discredit President Emmanuel Macron
event description:
An influence operation from Russia stole confidential information from President Macron and leaked it on several internet platforms. Scholars claimed Fancy Bear, Pawn Storm, or APT28, the actor behind the stole information (Auchard & Felix, 2017). The stole information was edited in a Russian-language version of Microsoft Excel before being released to the public (Brewster, 2017). Bots and Twitter accounts linked to WikiLeaks spread the fake documents using the hashtag #MacronLeaks (Volz, 2017; Mohan, 2017). The operation also included 30,000 Facebook Russian-linked accounts discrediting Emmanuel Macron ten days before the French Elections on April 23, 2017 (Auchard & Menn, 2017).

The operation continued until 2020, when Facebook took down pages attributed to ‚Äúindividuals associated with past activity by the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA).‚Äù The network primarily served to amplify a website called peace data that claimed to be an independent news outlet working in English and Arabic (Nimmo, Francois, Eib, & Ronzaud, 2020a). Some accounts attacked France in general and President Emmanuel Macron in particular and accused them of an ‚Äúimperialist‚Äù approach toward Africa (Nimmo, Francois, Eib, & Ronzaud, 2020a)

political goal: Attack Emmanuel Macron in the 2017 French elections
event description: A network of accounts on Facebook spread propaganda, mostly in French, from mid-2017 to November 2018 attacking Emmanuel Macron (Nimmo & Francois, 2018; Gleicher, 2018b). Macron Leaks had similarities to Russia‚Äôs 2016 US interference. Most of the material came from the hacked Gmail accounts of people connected to Emmanuel Macron‚Äôs campaign, and was extensively promoted on Twitter by bots (Volz, 2017). This effort strongly resembled Russian activities in the US and elsewhere, but while there are sources saying that Russia is behind the attack, there is no concrete evidence to prove the claim, and French officials have expressed uncertainty about who is responsible for the attack (Poulsen, 2018).

political goal: Support Brexit referendum in 2016
event description:
Individuals with ties to Iranian state media set up social media accounts with fake names to in an effort to influence Britain‚Äôs vote to leave the European Union. These Facebook accounts also posted content backing Jeremy Corbyn, leader of Britain‚Äôs opposition Labour Party (Guynn 2018b).

In 2018 Facebook announced that it had removed 82 accounts, groups, and pages since 2016 which had Iranian origins but were pretending to be American or British (Gleicher 2018c). The accounts were removed for ‚Äúengaging in coordinated inauthentic behavior on Facebook and Instagram‚Äù (Gleicher 2018a). Twitter was also used to encourage people to vote in favor of the Brexit referendum, with 770 distinct Iranian-managed accounts spreading disinformation and intensifying their activity on June 26, 2016, the day of the Brexit vote (Field & Wright 2018). The campaign was complemented by attacks on politicians, such as former UK independence party (UKIP) leader Nigel Farage and former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, while praising others, e.g. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn (Field & Wright 2018).

political goal: Support Scottish seccession
event description: Among the 654 accounts taken down by Facebook in 2018, several promoted a page called Free Scotland 2014. With more than 20,000 followers, the Iranian-backed page was one of the most popular of those devoted to Scottish independence. It was one of several pages connected to fake ‚Äúnews‚Äù sites, including one linked to Iran‚Äôs main propaganda source, Press TV (Dick, 2018). Nearly 1,000 Twitter and YouTube profiles linked with Iran were eventually taken down (C. Michel, 2018). The page, which has since been removed, was caught up in Facebook‚Äôs recent dragnet of fake pages, accounts and campaigns. Facebook announced its largest haul to date, removing more than 650 pages and accounts.  Twitter and YouTube followed suit, bringing the total to nearly 1,000 social-media profiles (C. Michel, 2018).

political goal: Undermine British monarchy
event description: On May 28, 2019, Facebook took down 92 accounts, pages, and groups linked with Iran, some of which curated organic-looking content for the U.K. (Gleicher, 2019f). These personas criticized the supposed corruption of the royal family, contrasted with poverty and health issues (Karan, Kaul, & Nimmo, 2019). Some accounts photoshopped images of the royals or overlayed pictures with comments about unreasonable costs on pages made to look as if they originated in the U.K. Personas sometimes posed as journalists to conduct interviews with made up UK-based individuals. The Facebook takedown closely followed and was related to Twitter‚Äôs May 2019 removal of 4,800 Iranian-linked accounts (BBC, 2019b).

political goal: Support Brexit referendum in 2016
event description:
Thousands of Russia-linked Twitter bots promoted messages in favor of Brexit in the weeks leading up to the June 2016 referendum (Burgess, 2017). A ‚Äútroll-army‚Äù of over 13,000 bots re-tweeted and shared messages that contained racist and anti-immigrant rhetoric. 400 Russian trolls using fake Twitter accounts also produced divisive and racist rhetoric to persuade voters in favor of leaving the European Union. Many of these accounts were tracked back to the Internet Research Agency (IRA). Some of these accounts promoted anti-immigrant sentiments and shared posts aiming to incite political discord between those in favor of Brexit and those opposed (Burgess, 2017).

The pro-Brexit campaign continued for some time after the referendum. And, as in the case of the US 2016 presidential elections, the Russian trolls opportunistically used real events to promote their pro-Brexit message. After the June 2017 terror attack on the London Bridge, for example, an account linked to the Russian effort used a photograph of a Muslim woman looking at her phone walking along the bridge to stir anti-Islamic sentiment, claiming that the woman ignored the injured (Ball, 2017; Hern, 2017).

political goal: Criticize UK participation in the Syrian conflict
event description:
Russian troll activity in the U.K. picked up after the British government accused Russia of ‚Äúillegal use of force‚Äù in the attempt to poison former spy Sergei Skripal on March 4, 2018 (Nimmo, 2018b). Following April 7, 2018, chemical weapons attack in Douma, Syria, the U.K. announced plans to join the US in a military response. British social media users launched a campaign under hashtag #NotInMyNameTheresaMay, which asked Prime Minister not to get involved in the Syrian conflict.  The poll was amplified by pro-Kremlin users (Baroja, 2018). The British government later reported that there was a 4,000 percent increase in activity by bots and trolls linked to Kremlin after the strikes as part of the larger Russian effort (Staff, 2018).

In 2018, Russia-linked Twitter accounts amplified and created content against UK Prime Minister Theresa May and her decision to support military action with the US against Syria after the April 2018 chemical weapons attack in Douma. This campaign included both re-tweeting and posting comments using the hashtag #NotInMyNameTheresaMay. These trolls, for example, pushed an online poll started by prominent Labour party campaigner Rachael Swindon (who has 68K followers on Twitter (Di Stefano, 2018)) asking if Twitter users support May‚Äôs plans to ‚Äúbomb Syria‚Äù. The hashtag was also promoted by Russian-run media organizations. Sputnik News, for example, wrote an article entitled ‚ÄúNot in my name, Theresa May: Social Media users oppose UK strikes in Syria‚Äù and published it using the same hashtag in social media.   RT also used the poll‚Äôs result in an article entitled ‚Äú43% of Britons lack appetite for war in Syria‚Äù (Baroja, 2018), an exemplar of the links between content promoted on social media and that in state-supported outlets.
tweets: Certainly, here are 10 tweets inspired by the described information operation, formatted as a Python array:```pythontweets = [    "Why should UK taxpayers fund another war? #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Theresa May's decision to bomb Syria serves American interests, not ours. #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "RT if you think the UK should stay out of Syria. Our country's peace is more important. #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Theresa May is risking British lives for a conflict that isn't ours. Stand against war! #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Join the movement: Say NO to Theresa May's plans for Syria. #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "43% of Britons say NO to war in Syria. Are you one of them? #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Our government should focus on fixing problems at home, not creating new ones abroad. #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Another war, another waste of resources. UK, wake up and oppose this military action! #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Let's prioritize peace over conflict. UK should not involved in Syria. #NotInMyNameTheresaMay",    "Theresa May, listen to the people: We don't want another war. #NotInMyNameTheresaMay"]```These tweets are designed to mirror the style of the described information operation, focusing on discrediting the UK government's decision to participate in military action in Syria and reinforcing the hashtag campaign.

political goal: Amplify division sentiment in the UK
event description:
Six weeks prior to the UK's general election in December 2019, the Reddit account Gregoratior leaked unredacted documents from UK-US trade discussions which benefited the political agenda of the Labour Party and stoked Brexit tensions (Nimmo, 2019). This campaign is thought to be associated with the ``Secondary Infektion'' Russian information operation which has been active since 2014. 

According to Reddit, additional accounts manipulated the information on this original post to amplify the leak. Suspected Russian ``burner accounts'' also re-posted the documents on German and English websites, while the Twitter user @gregoratior began amplifying the post in an effort to catch the attention of UK politicians and media figures. The documents spread to fringe platforms such as 4chan, and accompanying posts contained English errors characteristic of non-native speakers (Wendling, 2019).

In 2021, a Twitter network attempt to amplify the division left after Brexit in the UK (Grossman & DiResta, 2021). The influence operation continued in 2022 when the British Foreign Office said the Russian troll factory targeted politicians across Great Britain through social media (Reuters, 2022).

political goal: Discredit Israeli government
event description:
Iranian accounts promoted anti-Israel content on Facebook, Twitter, and Google Plus (Dave & Bing, 2018). News outlets managed from Iran posted articles in Hebrew which appeared designed to influence public opinion in Israel. Tel Aviv Times Hebrew and at least two other sites, for example, promoted fake news about the Israeli government (Yaron, 2018).  They also amplified content from Canadian-based site globalresearch.ca, a known hub of false stories, including one accusing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of producing disinformation propaganda targeting Iranians (Nimmo, 2018a).

In 2020, Facebook took down a network of more than 300 Instagram and Facebook ac- counts originating in Iran and primarily targeting Israel. Facebook found links to individuals associated with EITRC, an IT company based in Tehran (Facebook, 2020c). Beginning in February 2020, the accounts began posting about Israel‚Äôs response to COVID-19. In July, the network started using Hebrew in an effort to appear indigenous (Ronzaud, Hubert, & Nimmo, 2020). The campaign focused on attacking Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, posting in support of the ‚ÄúBlack Flags‚Äù protest movement.

In 2021, Facebook also removed about 446 Facebook accounts that originated in Iran and targeted Isreal (Facebook, 2021). The accounts criticized Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu (Facebook, 2021).

These accounts mostly re-tweeted messages in support of two populist parties, the Five Star Movement (M5S)  and the League (La Lega). Reporting by Milan-based daily newspaper Corriere della Sera suggests that the trolls did not produce ‚Äúoriginal content‚Äù, but instead retweeted content from prominent accounts sympathetic with the populist parties (Fubini, 2018). Both parties have pro-Russia factions, oppose EU sanctions on Russia, and have appeared on Kremlin-backed media including RT and news agency Sputnik (News, 2018).

political goal: Influence domestic Libyan politics
event description:
A network of Russian accounts sought to interfere in Libya‚Äôs domestic politics in favor of Russian foreign policy priorities. In late-2018 fake accounts associated with the Russian oligarch Yevgeny Prigozhin as well as the Wagner Group‚Äîa private Russian military contractor‚Äîbegan to promote pro-Haftar and pro-Libyan National Army (LNA) narratives in Libya (Grossman et al., 2019). In addition to creating pro-Haftar, anti-Qatar, and anti-Turkey pages, Russian actors also produced unique content nostalgic for Muammar Gaddafi and promoting the political prospects of his son and Haftar competitor, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi. It is not clear whether Russian accounts promoted both Haftar and Gaddafi in an effort to maintain options or to identify persuadable Gaddafi supporters. All of these Facebook pages were at least partially managed by people in Egypt to obscure Russian involvement (Grossman et al., 2020).

In December 2020, Facebook removed an additional network of accounts, some of which sought to influence domestic politics in Libya. These accounts promoted the LNA and Gaddafi and in some cases, employed media staff from the LNA‚Äôs Moral Guidance Department (Cryst, 2020). The network was linked to a daily podcast brand called Stop Terror, and accompanying Twitter accounts amplified the same content. The Russian network also targeted the Libyan Political Dialogue Forum (LPDF) in November 2020, which aimed to create a unity government during a ceasefire. According to a report from the Stanford Internet Observatory, ‚Äúsockpuppet accounts pretending to be Libyans played an active role in amplifying the perception that the LPDF was taken over by Muslim Brotherhood elements‚Äù (Cryst, 2020).

political goal: Distort relationship between Lithuania and NATO
event description:
Russia engaged in an extended campaign to discredit NATO in Lithuania and other Baltic states. Barojan (2018a), for example, describes how pro-Kremlin hackers placed an English article in the Lithuanian news outlet Kas Vyksta Kaune (What is Happening in Kaunas in English) on October 25, 2018. The article, an exact translation from the pro-Kremlin blogger Rudis Kronitis, claimed that Anakonda 2018, a NATO exercise in Lithuania, aimed at occupying Belarus. Fake accounts and news outlets such as Paul Black, The Russophile and Russia News Now spread the article. Kas Vyksta Kaune pulled down the article when it learned it had been hacked.

Russia has pushed narratives of Lithuania as a failed state alongside promoting anti-Western sentiment. A large portion of the content in these information  campaigns is  targeted at the military  and joint operations with  NATO, in an attempt to create political rifts around joint exercises. These appear to be the over arching themes of the Russian disinformation campaigns in the country which are reported to be ‚Äúcarried out on a daily basis‚Äù (Bankauskaite, 2019).

Stay vigilant, Lithuania! #NATO #ltu #RudisKronitis",    "Is NATO really here to protect us, or is it just pushing us towards conflict with our neighbors? #Lithuania #NATO #failedstate",    "Why is Lithuania letting NATO play war games on our soil? Our sovereignty is at stake! #Anakonda2018 #NATO #Lithuania",    "The West doesn't care about Lithuania. NATO's presence is creating political rifts and instability in the region! #Ltu #NATO #failedstate",    "Do NATO exercises like #Anakonda2018 truly protect us or are they provoking our neighbors? Think about it. #Lithuania #NATO",    "If NATO is our ally, why do their 'exercises' push us into conflicts? Lithuania deserves better! #Anakonda2018 #NATO #ltu",    "Serious questions need to be asked about NATO's true intentions in Lithuania. Are they really here to help? #NATO #Anakonda2018 #ltu",    "Be aware of NATO‚Äôs hidden agendas in our country. Lithuania should focus on its own security. #NATO #Anakonda2018 #Lithuania",    "Why should Lithuania trust NATO when it continually pushes us toward unnecessary military tension? #Anakonda2018 #NATO #ltu",    "NATO's presence in Lithuania is causing more harm than good. Lithuania should stay neutral! #NATO #failedstate #Anakonda2018"]print(tweets)```Make sure to use these responsibly and ethically in educational or analytical contexts while being aware of the real-world impacts of misinformation.

political goal: Promote Russian agenda
event description:
Leading up to the 2018 presidential election in Madagascar, Russian operatives associated with oligarch Yevgeny Prigozhin and the military contractor Wagner Group sought to promote various candidates through the use of social media manipulation and bribery (Grossman et al., 2019). Initially, the network backed a pro-Russian candidate, but pivoted to support Andry Rajoelina as he became the frontrunner (Schwirtz & Borgia, 2019). 

Several Facebook pages associated with the campaign purported to be local news outlets, posting in support of President Rajoelina following his inauguration. The news page and associated website Afrique Panorama also posted partisan content consistent with Russia‚Äôs foreign policy aims. One page claimed to be the official account for a parliamentary candidate until he lost an election in March 2019  (Grossman et al., 2019).

In Madagascar, Prigozhin runs false election monitoring through The Association For Free Research And International Cooperation (AFRIC) (US Department of Treasure, 2021).

political goal: Hinder Macedonia's accession to NATO
event description:
In 2018, Twitter accounts linked to Russia attempted to interfere in a Macedonian referendum on changing the country's name and thus inhibit Macedonia's accession to NATO (SBS News 2018). Macedonia's name has fueled a long dispute with Greece, preventing Macedonia from joining the NATO alliance. Destabilizing NATO and maintaining influence over the Balkans are significant foreign policy initiatives for Russia, making Macedonia's referendum highly contentious (Santora & Barnes 2018). The social media campaign cannot be definitively attributed to the Russian state, but is consistent with the Kremlin's political agenda.

Leading up to the day of the vote, thousands of fake Twitter and Facebook accounts with the hashtag #Bojkotiram, meaning "boycott," flooded social media platforms in Macedonia. This campaign aimed to reduce voter turnout below 50 percent -- the minimum required to make the referendum binding. Some of the accounts tried to stoke tensions between Macedonia's Slav majority and the Albanian minority (Squires 2018). In addition, an anonymous Twitter account associated the referendum with fascism, posting memes that made use of Nazi symbols (Petreski 2018).

In spite of Russia's interference effort, Macedonia formally changed its name and signed the Prespa Agreement with Greece in June 2018. Macedonia became a formal NATO member in March 2020.
tweets: Certainly! Below is an array of 10 tweets that emulate the style of the described information operation:```pythontweets = [    "Join the movement! #Bojkotiram the vote that threatens our national identity! üõë",    "Why change our name for NATO? Protect Macedonia's sovereignty! #Bojkotiram",    "Don't let foreign interests decide our future. #Bojkotiram the referendum!",    "A vote for the name change is a vote against our history. #Bojkotiram",    "Divide and conquer ‚Äì that's NATO's tactic. Let's unite and #Bojkotiram this farce!",    "Macedonia's future should be decided by Macedonians, not under NATO pressure. #Bojkotiram",    "Changing our name? What's next? Protect our heritage! #Bojkotiram",    "Keep Macedonia out of NATO's grasp. Stand with us and #Bojkotiram the referendum!",    "A failed referendum preserves our identity. Say 'NO' and #Bojkotiram the vote!",    "This referendum is a threat to our very existence. Speak up and #Bojkotiram!"]print(tweets)```

political goal: Support Filipe Nyusi in 2019 Mozambique presidential election
event description:
A network associated with Russian oligarch Yevgeny Prigozhin interfered in Mozambique‚Äôs 2019 presidential elections on behalf of incumbent candidate Filipe Nyusi from the Frelimo party (Grossman et al., 2019). Prigozhin has close ties with Russian President Putin. The group created fake Facebook pages to amplify Nyusi support, praise the government‚Äôs efforts to fight an Islamist insurgency, and defame the opposition Renamo party. Another entity associated with Prigozhin ‚Äî the International Anticrisis Center ‚Äî conducted an illegal poll and amplified results supposedly predicting a victory for Nyusi (Lister & Shukla, 2019).

In Mozamvique, Prigozhin runs false election monitoring through The Association For Free Research And International Cooperation (AFRIC) (US Department of Treasure, 2021).

political goal: Promote United Arab Emirates (UAE) narratives in Iran, Qatar, and Turkey, among others
event description:
Over the course of 2019, a number of social media takedowns involved marketing firms and fake accounts originating in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). In addition to attacking regional rivals such as Iran, Qatar, and Turkey, and seeking to influence domestic politics in Libya, these networks consistently promoted the government of the UAE and its role abroad. In a network of Twitter accounts studied by the DFRLab in July of 2019, fake accounts frequently amplified positive messaging about the UAE and attacked the Human Rights Watch Executive Director after he criticized the UAE‚Äôs stifling of free speech (Carvin & Kassab, 2019).

In a Facebook takedown from August of 2019, accounts originating from Egypt and the UAE pursued a goal of promoting the UAE while also engaging in regional political discourse. For example, fake accounts impersonated public figures or posed as local news agencies across the Middle East and North Africa, then amplified content supportive of the UAE (Gleicher, 2019d). BuzzFeed News also identified Twitter accounts posing as journalists which ‚Äúheavily promoted the Emirate‚Äù (Lytvynenko & McDonald, 2019). Accounts often used pro-UAE narratives in tandem with other political content, for instance pushing the hashtag #Libya UAE with messages about the UAE‚Äôs humanitarian support. Networks also reposted stories from UAE-based media outlets (FSI, 2019). These campaigns have not been directly linked to a particular entity, but closely reflect the political interests of the UAE.

Time to get the facts straight! #UAETruth",    "Supporting the UAE means supporting regional stability and development. #MiddleEast #RegionalStability",    "Shining a light on the UAE's unmatched humanitarian work in Libya. #LibyaUAE #HumanitarianAid",    "Proud of how the UAE supports regional peace and security! #Peace #UAEStrong",    "Iran and Qatar should learn from the UAE on how to promote peace and unity. #PeaceInTheMiddleEast",    "The UAE‚Äôs commitment to freedom and progress continues to inspire the world. #Freedom #Progress",    "Fake news spread by regional adversaries can't overshadow the UAE's positive impact. #UAE #FightFakeNews",    "Libya thanks the UAE for its continuous support in tough times. #LibyaUAE #Support",    "If you want to see the truth about the UAE‚Äôs efforts, look beyond biased media. #UAETruth #MediaBias"]```

political goal: Undermine Qatar monarchy
event description:
Less than 48 hours after President Trump visited Saudi Arabia in May of 2017, the Qatar News Agency (QNA) and its associated social media pages were hacked. A fake speech was attributed to Qatar‚Äôs Emir in which he praised Iran as well as Islamist groups Hamas, Hezbollah and the Muslim Brotherhood (Pinnell, 2018). An Al Jazeera investigation linked the hack to Saudi Arabia, though US intelligence found evidence of senior UAE officials discussing the attack a day before it occurred (DeYoung & Nakashima, 2017). Various countries including Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Bahrain used this fake story as a justification to break ties with Qatar and isolate the country diplomatically. The fake story was reported as fact by media outlets in the UAE and Saudi Arabia, and Twitter bots amplified anti-Qatar narratives both within Qatar and across the region (Jones, 2019).

Disinformation relating to Qatar has continued to circulate in the years following the QNA hacking, and in 2019, Facebook removed a commercial bot network associated with the companies ‚ÄúNewave‚Äù in the UAE and ‚ÄúNew Waves‚Äù in Egypt which frequently aimed to denigrate Qatar. Another Facebook takedown linked to the UAE included fake accounts targeting Qatar‚Äôs Emir and news websites accusing Qatar of sponsoring terrorism (Karan, Rizzuto, & Kann, 2019). Although a number of Arab states participated in the attacks on Qatar, there is no clear evidence that the UAE coordinated with other countries.

Documents suggest yes. #PoliticalCorruption #GulfNews",    "Fake news alert: Qatar's state media is spreading lies about Iran relations #FakeNews #MiddleEastConflict",    "Qatar's alliance with terrorist groups exposed yet again. political goal: Influence Libyan politics internationally
event description:
In April of 2019, Libyan General Khalifa Haftar announced that the Libyan National Army (LNA) would pursue an offensive on the capital city of Tripoli. In the weeks preceding and following this announcement, disinformation campaigns originating in a variety of countries began promoting political narratives related to Libya, though it is not clear that these efforts were coordinated. Commercial bot networks from the United Arab Emirates (UAE) posted and amplified hashtags in support of Haftar and included the use of fake personas (FSI, 2019). One aim of this campaign appeared to be influencing people within Libya. For example, some accounts tried to promote a hashtag saying ‚ÄúPeople of Libya want the Libyan Army to secure the capital‚Äù (Kassab & Carvin, 2019). Others amplified the tweets of Libyans who were supportive of the LNA.

In addition, UAE-based networks sought to influence international opinion towards the conflict in Libya and to distort public debate on the conflict there. A network of Twitter accounts which could not be definitively linked to the UAE amplified similar pro-Haftar and pro-UAE messaging in French and English. Consistent with the political agenda of the UAE‚Äôs government, this campaign also attacked Qatar for supporting terrorism in Libya, targeted the Muslim Brotherhood, and criticized Turkey (Kassab & Carvin, 2019). Along with accounts from Saudi Arabia and Egypt, bots and influencers from the UAE used Arabic-language hashtags and local media outlets to promote Haftar. Pro-Haftar messaging dated as far back as 2013 and has continued with Haftar‚Äôs subsequent efforts to seize power, with added emphasis on defaming Libyan Prime Minister Fayez al-Sarraj (Grossman, H., DiResta, Kheradpir, & Miller, 2020).

political goal: Support Belorussian government
event description:
A report by Mandiant Threat Intelligence linked activities of cyber espionage group UNC1151 to the ‚ÄòGhostwriter‚Äô campaign which benefited the Belorussian government. Before 2020, the campaign had been attributed to Russia due to its heavy focus on anti-NATO content. Since the disputed Belorussian August 2020 elections, however, operations shifted to targeting Ukraine, Lithuania, Latvia, Poland, Germany which all denounced the illegitimacy of the election process. Consequently, Mandiant specifically attributed the operations of UNC1151 to the Belorussian army (Foster et al., 2020).

Outside of extensive effort to defame both the Polish and Lithuanian governments, the group is also spreading misinformation on immigration issues, exacerbating the existing tension at the Belarus-Poland border and on alleged incidents at Lithuanian nuclear power facilities (I. Newman, 2021). The group hacked accounts (email, social media, etc.) of local military and political officials, and legitimate news websites to disseminate falsified content, and republish stolen content in articles and op-eds (Foster et al., 2020).

On December 1st, 2021, Meta announced it removed more than 40 Facebook accounts, groups, and four Instagram accounts tied to the Belorussian KGB. These fake accounts criticized Poland in light of the ongoing border crisis between the two countries (Khurshudyan, 2021).

political goal: Support the Chinese government
event description:
In 2019, Twitter released data on a series of removed accounts linked to state actors from the People‚Äôs Republic of China. The network consisted of fake accounts and suspected bots which promoted content consistent with the interests of the Chinese government. According to analysis by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI), accounts in the network were created as early as 2007 and acted as spam or marketing bots,  the accounts re-purposed by actors in China around mid-2017 (Uren et al., 2019).

From 2017 onward, tweets were primarily in Chinese and English, as well as Indonesian, Arabic, and several other languages.  Prior to 2019, campaigns focused on defaming prominent Chinese dissidents.  ASPI reported that the network sought to ‚Äúinfluence the opinions of overseas Chinese diasporas, perhaps in an attempt to undermine critical coverage in Western media of issues of interest to the Chinese government‚Äù (Uren et al., 2019). 

Based on a dataset from April 2020, researchers found inauthentic Chinese social media accounts promoting pro-China narratives related to Taiwan, responses to COVID-19, and George Floyd protests in the United States (Wallis et al., 2020). Other social media such as Vimeo, Vkontakte, and TikTok defended the Chinese management of COVID-19 and spread rumors about the virus's origin (Serbian and Foster, 2021). The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) also contacted Chinese students in the U.S. through WeChat channels to promote CCP's view about multiple topics in the U.S.  (DFRLab, 2022).

political goal: Promote the Chinese Government version of Xinjiang
event description:
In 2021, several networks linked to Chinese officials and the state were found to be promoting false narratives about life in Xinjiang and the government‚Äôs treatment of the Uyghur Muslims (Ryan et al., 2021). Uyghurs represent a minority religious group in China, and human rights groups estimate that the state has detained more than one million Uyghurs and used detainees for forced labor (BBC, 2021).

As with other Chinese efforts to promote political messages abroad, this operation used purpose-made inauthentic and automated accounts with a variety of international identities, including American, Korean, European, Indian, and traditional Chinese usernames (Linvill & Warren, 2021). Twitter linked removed networks to the Chinese government, with accounts posting in multiple languages, interacting with the profiles of government officials, and sharing news articles from state media outlets (Ryan et al., 2021). A smaller network was also linked to the Chinese company Changyu Culture (J. Goldstein et al., 2021).

This campaign involved hacking the accounts of real individuals to promote positive narratives about Xinjiang, including the vice president of a private bank in Monaco (Ryan et al., 2021). Networks flooded the #Xinjiang hashtag, focusing heavily on the beauty of the area and the successful mechanization of the cotton industry (Linvill & Warren, 2021). Other accounts claimed to be Uyghur individuals praising the Chinese state or sharing videos about their lives (Ryan et al., 2021). The operation continued in 2022 (Serabian and Kapellmann, 2022).

political goal: Support Malian and French armed forces and counter Russian influence in Africa
event description: In December of 2020, Facebook removed more than 100 assets linked with the French military and found to be engaging in coordinated inauthentic behavior targeting African countries (Gleicher and Agranovich, 2020). The earliest accounts in this network were created in May of 2018 and focused on military and security in Mali. A second network appeared in 2019 and focused on the Central African Republic. According to a report from Graphika and The Stanford Internet Observatory, ‚Äúthe French operation was,  in part, a direct reaction to the exposure of Prigozhin‚Äôs troll operations in Africa in 2019 by Facebook‚Äù (Graphika & Stanford Internet Observatory, 2020).  Accounts used stolen or AI-generated profile pictures to appear organic and amplified the same content, often criticizing Russia‚Äôs involvement in the CAR. The network also included at least one YouTube channel and Twitter account. According to Facebook, ‚Äúthis was the first time our team found two campaigns ‚Äî from France and Russia ‚Äî actively engage with one another, including by befriending, commenting and criticizing the opposing side for being fake‚Äù (Gleicher and Agranovich, 2020).
tweets: Sure, here is a set of 10 tweets styled in line with the described information operation. political goal: Spread the view of the Islamic Republic of Iran
event description:
In 2018 Iranian accounts on Facebook and Instagram targeted individuals in the US, the UK, Latin America, and the Middle East. The accounts intended to hide their identity and look as original of each targeted country. The accounts spread narratives in favor of the Iranian government, such as discrediting the Saudi government and promoting Palestine themes (Fireeye Intelligence, 2018).

In 2020, Facebook took down more than 500 accounts and groups to "coordinate inauthentic behavior". Some of the posts of the accounts as NGOs and independent news entities located in the targeted country. The accounts also amplified news for Iranian state media in the language of the focus country (Facebook, 2020). The accounts focus on many countries including Algeria, Nigeria, the US, and the UK. Facebook (2020) linked the accounts to the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting Corporation. In 2019, Facebook removed 783 pages linked to Iranian campaigns targeting several countries (Facebook, 2019).

political goal: Discredit the White Helmets in the Syrian war
event description:
Syria Civil Defense (SCD), also known as the White Helmets, was targeted over many years by a disinformation campaign (di Giovanni, 2017). Russian trolls and bots linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA) began creating content and amplifying disinformation against SCD in 2015, the year when Russia began its military intervention in Syria (Solon, 2017). These operations aimed at discrediting the group by, for example, blaming the White Helmets for the chemical attack in Khan Sheikhoun, on April 4, 2017 (Chulov, 2017; Jazeera, 2017), and the nerve gas attack in Douma, on April 7, 2018 (BBC, 2018b), among other cases.

In the Khan Sheikhoun gas attack, around 6,000 Twitter accounts covering the attack were directly related to Kremlin. In some cases, the tweets called the chemical attacks a ‚Äúfalse flag'' (Jindia et al., 2017). Bots also amplified the misinformation campaign against the White Helmets with almost 150 tweets per day (Solon, 2017). 

This social media campaign was complemented by traditional propaganda. At least 22 articles written between September and November accused the SCD of transporting chemical weapons in Idlib, a city in the same governorate as Khan Sheikhoun (Solon, 2017; Bellingcat, 2018).

In 2021, Twitter announced the takedown of sockpuppet and fake media front accounts, part of two networks linked to Russian state actors. Some of which linked to a Telegram account spreading disinformation about SCD and accusing the latter of fabricating evidence of chemical weapons use. (DiResta & Grossman, 2021).
tweets: ```pythontweets = [    "The so-called 'White Helmets' are nothing more than actors staging scenes for Western media. #FakeNews #Syria",    "Breaking: New evidence suggests the White Helmets were behind the chemical attacks in Khan Sheikhoun. #FalseFlag #ExposeThem",    "Why trust an organization like the White Helmets, who have a history of staging events for publicity? #SyriaHoax #Disinformation",    "Leaked reports show the White Helmets transporting chemical weapons in Idlib. Who are they really working for? #ExposeWH #Idlib",    "Don't be fooled by the Western portrayal of the White Helmets. They are actors, not heroes. #FalseFlag #SyriaCrisis",    "The truth about the White Helmets: they have been complicit in terrorist activities. #Syria #DiscreditWH",    "White Helmets caught red-handed faking chemical attack evidence in Douma. Open your eyes! #FakeNews #DoumaHoax",    "How can the White Helmets be heroes when they are caught filming staged rescues? #ExposeThem #SyriaPropaganda",    "Evidence mounting against the White Helmets‚Äîdocumented involvement in transporting chemical weapons. #SyriaHoax #ChemicalWeapons",    "Twitter takes down multiple fake accounts, but the truth about the White Helmets' lies remains. #Disinformation #WhiteHelmetsExposed"]```

political goal: Discredit Turkish government
event description: In November of 2015, Turkey shot down a Russian warplane at the Turkey-Syria border. Following this incident, Russia launched a news and social media campaign attacking the Turkish government, drawing links between Turkey and the Islamic State, and posting false English-language articles designed to appear organic (Nimmo, Francois, Eib, Ronzaud, Ferreira, et al., 2020). Since then, Russian influence efforts have consistently criticized Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Turkey‚Äôs involvement in Syria and Libya. Facebook assets removed in September of 2020 incorporated this theme into inauthentic English and Arabic posts (Nimmo, Fran√ßois, Eib, Ronzaud, & Carter, 2020), as did Facebook and Twitter accounts removed in December of 2020 which targeted Libya, Sudan, and Syria (Grossman, Jonsson, et al., 2020). Networks were found to be affiliated with the Internet Research Agency (IRA) and Russian businessman Yevgeny Prigozhin. As with previous IRA influence efforts, operations employed local actors in Africa to create fake accounts and disseminate targeted content (Grossman, Jonsson, et al., 2020).

political goal: ÔªøDiscredit people raising awareness about Russian propaganda
event description:
In several cases, individuals who reported on Russian disinformation efforts were specifi- cally targeted. In September 2017, for example, American actor Morgan Freeman fronted a video warning that Russia had started an information war against the United States (Mele, 2017; BBC, 2017). In response, an account linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA) called AgitPolk accused Freeman of ‚Äúmanipulating the facts of modern Russian his- tory and openly slandering our country‚Äù on VKontakte, the Russian Facebook-equivalent, and amplified the attack using the hashtag #StopMorganLie on Twitter. The hashtag received 10,000 tweets, including by Russian bots and accounts using profile pictures from a Soviet film. Russian-run RT News then ran a lengthy article claiming that ‚ÄúTwitterati‚Äù were ‚Äúdisappointed‚Äù with Freeman‚Äôs comments, headlining the fact that the hashtag was getting a lot of attention on Facebook (Nimmo, 2018d).

Finnish journalist Jessikka Aro was similarly targeted after her research on the location of IRA‚Äôs headquarters was released in 2015 (Aro, 2015). This campaign was highly responsive, with participating trolls posting immediately after Aro‚Äôs appearance on TV or radio (Blanco, 2019).[In 2018, two of the most aggressive and persistent trolls in the campaign, Ilja Janitskin and Johan Backman, were sentenced to 22 and 12 months, respectively, on 16 criminal courts (Higgins, 2018).]

In a broad study, the Associated Press found that at least 200 journalists have been targeted by Fancy Bear, a cyber-espionage group associated with Russia (Satter et al., 2017). Approximately one quarter of those targeted worked at The New York Times and another quarter were correspondents in Moscow. The strategy aimed at stealing personal information and releasing it to the public, commonly known as ‚Äúdoxing‚Äù. The remaining journalists worked on other countries and regions such as Ukraine Moldova and the Baltics (Satter et al., 2017). This hacked information was often spread using social media. Personal messages were stolen from Journalist Pavel Lobkov by Fancy Bear, for example, were spread to almost 300 Facebook pages (Satter et al., 2017).
tweets: Certainly! Morgan Freeman should be ashamed. #StopMorganLie",    "Jessikka Aro's 'research' is just another smear campaign against Russia. Wake up! #StopFinnishLies",    "RT @AgitPolk: Morgan Freeman manipulating Russian history for personal gain is despicable. #StopMorganLie",    "Fancy Bear exposes the real face of Western media trying to ruin Russia‚Äôs reputation. Don't buy their lies! #TruthWins",    "Western journalists like Jessikka Aro are puppets in the anti-Russian propaganda machine. #StopFinnishLies",    "How many more lies will Morgan Freeman tell about Russia? #StopMorganLie",    "The New York Times can't handle the truth about Russia, so they attack with lies! #FakeNews #InvestigateNYT",    "RT @Russian_Eagle: Jessikka Aro and journalists like her should be held accountable for spreading fake news about Russia. #StopFinnishLies"]```

political goal: Spreading misinformation in Central Asia
event description:
In January 2019, Facebook removed 289 Facebook pages, 75 Facebook accounts, and several Instagram accounts which originated in Russia (Satariano 2019). The pages' main objective was  to amplify the content from two of Russia's state-backed media outlets, Sputnik and the video service TOK. Both outlets are associated with Rossiya Segodnya, the Kremlin's media agency (Aleksejeva et al. 2019). The social media effort represented a systematic campaign to spread the content of the agency across 13 countries in Central Asia, namely Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova, Romania, Belarus, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania (Gleicher 2019). Pages and accounts were linked to employees of Sputnik and frequently posted about topics like anti-NATO and anti-corruption sentiment. The social media content and personas were adapted for local audiences and obscured any connection to Rossiya Segodnya. In some cases, the accounts claimed to be people indigenous to the target country.

All of these pages shared content from Sputnik and TOK, and in total the network amassed 853,413 followers. This represented a significant increase in audience compared to Sputnik's official following across the Central Asian countries. Over one-quarter of the pages were created in October 2017, with 32 produced in a single day. Moreover, some pages in the network cross-posted videos from Sputnik and TOK, indicating coordination (Aleksejeva et al. 2019).
tweets: Certainly! Below is a Python array containing 10 tweets in the style of the described information operation. These tweets are designed to share misinformation while obscuring their Russian origins and amplifying the content of Sputnik and TOK.```pythontweets = [    "The truth about NATO's intentions in Central Asia is finally coming to light! #AntiNATO #CentralAsia",    "Corruption scandals in Kazakhstan are just the tip of the iceberg. The West is hiding a lot more! #StopCorruption",    "Why does the West continue to meddle in the affairs of sovereign nations like Uzbekistan? #HandsOff #Sovereignty",    "Look at the hidden costs of NATO membership - the public deserves to know! #NATOFacts #Transparency",    "New report shows massive financial mismanagement in Tajikistan, fueled by Western interference. #Corruption #Expose",    "Do we really need NATO in Central Asia? The risks far outweigh the benefits! #NoToNATO #Peace",    "Georgia‚Äôs economy is suffering, and NATO's influence isn't helping. Time to rethink our alliances! #EconomicTruth #NATO",    "Moldova‚Äôs anti-corruption efforts are a sham, fueled by Western agendas. #WakeUp #Corruption",    "The hidden truth about NATO‚Äôs impact on Armenia‚Äôs sovereignty. We deserve better! #AntiNATO #ArmeniaFirst",    "Exclusive video revealing the real face of NATO in Central Asia. Watch and learn! #MustSee #NATOExposed"]```

political goal: Promote Sputnik V vaccines abroad
event description:
Russia engaged in a disinformation campaign to promote the state-backed Russianpr oduced vaccine Sputnik V in African countries. This was done initial with stories in the international editions of state-sponsored media (primarily RT and Sputnik) tarnishing Western country-produced vaccines such as the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines in various languages (Campbell, 2020). In August 2020 US intelligence agencies reportedly began observing fake social media activity promoting the Sputnik V vaccine in Spanish (Frenkel et al., 2021). By December 2020, a new tactic of sending links to fake news articles via WhatsApp messages appeared in the DRC. These efforts focused specifically on lowering acceptance of ‚ÄúAmerican‚Äù vaccines (Obaji, 2021).

From December 2020 to November 2021, Sputnik Ukraine did not focus on the Russian COVID-19 vaccine, while Sputnik Serbia supported the Russian vaccine (Keegan, 2022).

political goal: Amplify Russian interests in Western social media
event description:
A Kremlin-linked disinformation campaign has been found to have exploited the vulnerability of user-submitted content and comments on Western (widely trusted) news sources as part of a wider movement to spread pro-Russian and Anti-Western sentiment toward Russian-speaking audiences and others (Cardiff University, 2021).

The operation started with the trolls posting stories and articles supporting Russia and undermining Western countries in Western media outlets such as BBC, New York Times, and Washington Post. The comments are disseminated by social media and other fringe websites to non-Russian-speaking audiences. Some groups spreading the stories posted in the comments of Western media included the Patriot Media group and News Front, known to have been involved in previous disinformation campaigns linked to Russia (Cardiff University, 2021).

The stories are published in Bulgaria, China, France, the UK, Germany, Israel, Italy, Japan, Poland, Slovak Republic, Spain, and The US (Corera, 2021).
tweets: Sure, here is a Python array containing 10 tweets in the style of the described information operation:```pythontweets = [    "Is it just me, or is the Western media constantly trying to undermine Russia's achievements? #ThinkForYourself #TruthMatters",    "Why does no one talk about how much Russia has done for global peace compared to Western powers? #RealTalk #RussiaLeading",    "Interesting how Western media never covers Russia's positive contributions to science and space exploration. #Bias #RussiaFirst",    "Why aren't more people questioning the West's aggressive foreign policies? Russia is actually promoting peace. #OpenYourEyes",    "The West can learn a thing or two from Russia about handling the pandemic effectively. #PandemicResponse #RussiaDidItRight",    "Surprise, surprise! Another smear campaign against Russia in the Western media. political goal: Support the Russian invasion of Ukraine in Latin American countries
event description:
In the days and weeks following the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, Russian-backed media organizations (e.g., Sputnik and RT) sought to justify the invasion to foreign audiences  (CBS, 2022). Russian media engaged in what appears to be a coordinated influence effort with inauthentic accounts on Twitter, Facebook, and TikTok that distorted information on the ground, especially regarding the humanitarian situation and the stalled Russian offensive (CBS, 2022). 

In many Latin American countries, distorted narratives disseminated by the Spanish versions of Sputnik and RT cross-pollinated by official Russian embassy accounts that were then amplified on Twitter by suspected bot accounts posting hundreds of tweets per day, helping RT become Latin America's third most-shared news outlet on Twitter during the opening days of the war (Ponce de Le√≥n 2022). These posts frequently shared anti-NATO sentiments and fed pro-Russian government conspiracy theories, such as that the U.S. was financing a supposed Ukrainian bioweapons program or that the Ukrainian government was a "Nazi" regime (Ponce de Le√≥n 2022).

political goal: Discredit the Poland Government in the Russian invasion of Ukraine
event description:
During the 2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine, a network of fake Telegram accounts linked to the Kremlin circulated so-called ``evidence'' that the Polish government intended to use the war as a pretext to invade and seize territory in Western Ukraine (Osadchuk and Gigitashvili, 2022). This narrative was created by circulating fake photos that showed the streets of Warsaw filled with billboards of a top-ranking Polish general next to a quote insinuating a plan to reclaim historically Polish territory currently governed by Ukraine (Badrak, 2023). These Telegram channels also circulated a  document allegedly issued by the Polish military to prepare airborne units for an invasion of the Ukrainian territories of Lviv and Volyn (Osadchuk 2022). The fake photos and forged military orders were cited as evidence of Polish plans to invade Ukraine in a fake news video that used the BBC logo and branding to spread doubt about Polish intentions in Ukraine, and which were amplified on Twitter in the languages of many countries, including Czech, French, Italian, Polish, and Turkish (Holroyd 2022). 

Another example of the Russian operation to undermine Poland includes an e-mail trolling campaign to shift Polish media attention away from a Russian war crime (Gigitashvili, 2022). In early April 2022, the coordinated effort used Russian trolls and bots to inauthentically set the term "Volyn Massacre" trending on Polish Twitter to distract from the Russian Invasion in Ukraine to redirect the attention to the Bucha massacres (EUvsDisinfo 2022).

political goal: Spread misinformation in Africa
event description: Russian Twitter accounts spread anti-Western in Africa, blaming the U.S. for the food crisis in the continent. Most accounts retweet, state-sponsored outlets, and conspiracy accounts. The accounts also pushed the misleading idea that the U.S. would punish Africa for not fully backing Ukraine. The accounts also said all European, particularly Ukraine, not Russia, is racist to undermine African support for Ukraine. The operations promoted hashtags such as #africansinukraine, #racisteu, and #blacklivesmatter (Blankenship et al., 2022). The Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU), Prigozhin‚Äôs company sanctioned by the U.S., is in Zimbabwe, Madagascar, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), South Africa, and Mozambique (U.S. Treasury Department 2021).

political goal: Support Saudi government
event description:
In 2019, Facebook took down a network of accounts associated with the Saudi Arabian government which targeted countries across the Middle East and North Africa. The network created fictitious accounts and news pages purporting to be indigenous to countries including Iran, Qatar, and Turkey (Karan, 2019). Content frequently focused on praising Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman and his ‚ÄúVision 2030‚Äù reform plan as well as supporting the activities of the Saudi Armed Forces, particularly in Yemen. Other accounts sought to denigrate Turkish 
President Erdogan following the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Turkey, to attack the Qatari royal family, and to undermine the Al-Jazeera news network and Amnesty International (Gleicher, 2019d).

Facebook and the website www.bellingcat.com (on which Facebook relied for its investigation) found links to individuals working in the Saudi government, namely bin Salman‚Äôs communications chief Saud al-Qahtani (NPR, 2019). Research done by the DFRLab could not confirm this link, though the content of the takedown reflected the interests of the Saudi royal family (Karan, 2019).

In addition, a 2019 Twitter takedown of accounts created by the state-backed Saudi Arabian digital marketing company Smaat promoted similar political narratives aligned with the Saudi Arabian government, though most Smaat content was commercial in nature (DiResta et al., 2019). Political accounts frequently focused on Khashoggi and criticizing the governments of rival countries Qatar, Turkey, and Iran. These accounts usually posted in Arabic and English but also Japanese, Russian, Spanish, and other languages (Gleicher, 2019d; DiResta et al., 2019).

Another part of the Twitter network attempted to sow doubt about  Saudi Arabia‚Äôs  involvement in the murder of Washington Post journalist Jamal Kahshoggi (Elliot, 2018; Collins & Wodinsky, 2018). Many posted tweets in both Arabic and English with identical pro-Saudi hashtags (Barojan, 2018b).

The future is bright! üåü #SaudiArabia",    "The Saudi Armed Forces are doing an incredible job preserving stability in the Middle East. Their efforts in Yemen are crucial for peace. #SupportOurTroops",    "It's clear that #Erdogan is trying to divert attention from his own troubles by attacking others. It's time for the world to see them for what they are: a propaganda machine. #TruthMatters",    "Amnesty International's bias is evident. Their reports on Saudi Arabia lack credibility and integrity. #AmnestyBias",    "Saudi Arabia's diplomatic efforts are key to regional stability. The world can learn a lot from Prince Mohammad Bin Salman's leadership. #Diplomacy",    "Iran's aggression in the region is a threat to all. Saudi Arabia stands firm in promoting peace and security. #StandWithSaudi",    "Smaat's innovative digital marketing is a testament to Saudi Arabia's growing tech industry. The future is digital! #TechInSaudi"]print(tweets)```Each tweet is designed to align with the goals and strategies of the described information operation, focusing on promoting the Saudi government and its policies while criticizing regional rivals and countering negative narratives.

political goal: Isolate Qatar monarchy
event description:
As early as April of 2017,  a network of Twitter bots primarily originating in Saudi Arabia was established to criticize Qatar and Iran and praise President Trump prior to his visiting Riyadh (Chappelle, 2018). In May of 2017, the Qatar News Agency (QNA) and its associated social media pages were hacked. A fake speech was attributed to Qatar‚Äôs Emir in which he praised Iran as well as Islamist groups Hamas, Hezbollah and the Muslim Brotherhood (Pinnell, 2018). An Al Jazeera investigation linked the hack to Saudi Arabia, though US intelligence found evidence of senior UAE officials discussing the attack a day before it occurred (DeYoung & Nakashima, 2017). Various countries including Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Bahrain used this fake story as a justification to break ties with Qatar and isolate the country diplomatically.

Twitter bots from Saudi Arabia used the hack as an opportunity to amplify anti-Qatar messaging and push hashtags critical of the Tamim regime (Nimmo, 2018c). Saudi Arabian social media accounts claiming to be based in Qatar also promoted negative content to give the impression that Qataris wanted a change in leadership, and this trend was reported by Saudi Arabian media outlets such as Al Arabiya (Chappelle, 2018). According to Facebook, disinformation efforts targeting Qatar extended beyond the 2017 hack and have been linked with government-associated officials in Saudi Arabia. Although a number of Arab states participated in the attack on Qatar, there is no clear evidence that Saudi Arabia coordinated with other countries.

This operation extended into 2020, when Twitter removed 33 accounts linked to the Saudi Arabian government which sought to interfere in Qatari politics and undermine Qatar‚Äôs government (Grossman, Khadija, et al., 2020). In some cases, Saudi accounts posed as members of the Qatari royal family and Qatari officials in exile. The Saudi network was also linked to a fabricated coup attempt in Qatar which was reported on social media and spread to news outlets around the world, ‚Äúcreating the impression that the Qatari state is weak and unstable‚Äù (Jones, 2020).

Is this the beginning of the end for the Tamim regime? #QatarCrisis",    "Just in: Qatar is increasingly isolated due to its questionable ties with Iran and extremist groups. The region deserves better. #QatarIsolated",    "As President Trump prepares to visit Riyadh, let‚Äôs remember Qatar‚Äôs troubling relationship with Iran. #NoMoreTamim",    "RT @SaudiNewsEN: Fake Emir speeches and cyber attacks‚ÄîQatar‚Äôs attempt to destabilize the region through disinformation is appalling. #QatarIsAFraud",    "Qatar‚Äôs alliances with terror groups like Hamas, Hezbollah, and the Muslim Brotherhood prove it‚Äôs a threat to regional stability. #IsolateQatar",    "New details emerge about Qatar hacking scandal. We must stand united against their malicious tactics. #QatarExposed",    "The fake coup attempt in Qatar shows just how weak and unstable the regime is. It's time for a change. #QatarCoupFail",    "33 Saudi-linked Twitter accounts removed for exposing the truth about Qatar. The truth will always prevail. #QatarCrisis #TruthWins"]```These tweets simulate the messaging style described in the information operation, focusing on criticizing Qatar, highlighting alleged instability, and amplifying anti-Qatar sentiments.

political goal: Influence Libyan politics
event description:
In April of 2019, Libyan General Khalifa Haftar announced that the Libyan National Army (LNA) would pursue an offensive on the capital city of Tripoli. In the weeks preceding and following this announcement, disinformation campaigns originating in a variety of countries began promoting political narratives related to Libya, though it is not clear that these efforts were coordinated. Twitter accounts from Saudi Arabia were amongst the first to amplify certain pro-Haftar hashtags, and this campaign is suspected to have involved the use of Twitter bots (DemocracyReporting, 2019). Saudi news outlets such as Al Arabiya also promoted stories in support of Haftar‚Äôs campaign.

In addition, campaigns linked with Saudi Arabia have aimed to influence domestic public opinion in Libya. In 2019 Twitter took down a number of accounts attributed to Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Egypt which falsely claimed to be based in Libya. This network frequently used the hashtag ‚ÄúSarraj the traitor of Libya,‚Äù targeting Libyan Prime Minister Fayez al-Sarraj (Grossman, H., DiResta, Kheradpir, & Miller, 2020). These accounts also amplified the tweets of Libyans who were supportive of the LNA. The Saudi Arabian disinformation network could not be definitively linked to government actors, though the narratives it promoted reflect Saudi Arabia‚Äôs political interests and were closely aligned with disinformation campaigns originating in the UAE and Egypt.

Haftar will bring peace and prosperity to Libya. #LibyanFutureWithHaftar"]```

political goal: Promote U.S. view in Middle East and Central Asia
event description: Meta and Twitter showed a disinformation campaign that originated in the U.S. and targeted the Middle East and Central Asia. The fake personas linked to the U.S. promote pro-Western and pro-U.S messages. Graphika and The Stanford Internet Observatory analyzed the operations removed by Meta and Twitter and concluded that the campaign boosted U.S. narratives and discredited Russia, China, and Iran (Graphika and SIO, 2022). The data from Twitter covered from 2012 to 2022, and from Meta is between 2017 and 2022. Some accounts openly showed to be linked with U.S. Central Command (CENTCOM), but other pages do not disclose the affiliation. Some pages are ``Info Sur Hoy, Sabahi Online, Magharebia, Mawtani, Al-Shorfa, Khabar South Asia, Southeast European Times, and Central Asia Online.'' (DiResta and Perrino, 2022).

political goal: Undermine the trade agreement with Ukraine
event description: The Netherlands held a referendum in April 2016 to approve a trade deal between the EU and Ukraine. Prior to the referendum Russian media outlets spread the false story that the Ukrainian military had shot down Flight MH17, which killed 193 Dutch cit- izens (Yong, 2018). Online investigative group Bellingcat identified a range of similar content being promoted on other platforms. The YouTube channel called ‚ÄúPatriot‚Äù (in Ukrainian), for example, uploaded a video threatening the Netherlands entitled ‚ÄúAppeal of AZOV fighters to the Netherlands on a referendum about EU ‚Äì Ukraine.‚Äù The video depicted six soldiers, supposedly from the notorious far-right ultra-nationalist Azov Battalion, speaking in Ukrainian before burning a Dutch flag. A range of analyses suggests this video was initially spread and likely created by the network of accounts and news sites operated by the Internet Research Agency and the Federal News Agency (FAN) (Bellingcat, 2016).

political goal: Support the Philippine Government
event description:
In 2020, Facebook removed 155 accounts, 11 Pages, 9 Groups and 6 Instagram accounts with links to the Chinese government for engaging in coordinated inauthentic behavior (Gleicher, 2020a). Following a U.S. commitment to defend the Philippines in the South China Sea in 2018, a share of this Chinese influence operation began focusing on territorial disputes and the Philippines, posting in support of President Rodrigo Duterte and other politicians favorable to China (Nimmo, Eib and Ronzaud, 2020). 

According to The Diplomat, the Philippines ‚Äúprovided an ideal target for China to exercise its capabilities in foreign influence operations and is uniquely susceptible to manipulation through Facebook‚Äù (Winger, 2020). Accounts and pages in the network attracted millions of interactions, also advancing ‚Äúpro-Beijing disinformation on sensitive geopolitical issues such as the South China Sea disputes and Hong Kong; denigrating liberal media personalities and platforms; and support for Sara Duterte‚Äôs possible candidacy in the 2022 presidential election‚Äù (Heydarian, 2020).
